guide.title: Working with the VDR Overlays
guide.abstract: This document explains how to install software straight from our overlays.

chapter.title: Configuration and usage of the overlays

body.p: An overlay is simply the place where people put third party ebuilds. These ebuilds undergo extensive testing before they can be put into the Portage tree. Currently there are two overlays available: vdr-testing and vdr-1.5. If you want software around the VDR which is tested to become finally part of the main tree you can use the vdr-testing overlay. If you want the most recent development versions of the VDR you have to use the vdr-1.5 overlay. In the following we use the vdr-testing overlay as example.
Before we can install packages from an overlay, we need to install layman, an overlay manager. For more information, see the layman project page.
Even though we've installed layman, we can't install packages just yet. First you will need to tell Portage you want to use a local repository. This can be done with these simple commands:
body.pre: (First we create a needed file. It's alright if it already exists.) # touch /usr/portage/local/layman/make.conf # echo "source /usr/portage/local/layman/make.conf" >> /etc/make.conf
body.p: Next, we'll have layman check out (svn co) the repository for /usr/portage/local/layman/vdr-testing/:
Now you can start using the ebuilds from the VDR overlay. Point your browser to http://overlays.gentoo.org/proj/vdr/browser/testing and choose a few packages.
